00086 /*==========================================================================*
00087  * REGISTER ALLOCATOR USER INTERFACE FUNCTIONS,STRUCTURES, AND INSTRUCTIONS *
00088  *==========================================================================*/
00089 
00090 /*
00091  * Register Bank Definition:
00092  *
00093  *     The register allocator allocates registers from a linear
00094  *     virtual register file, with the registers numbered from
00095  *     R[0..N].  Mapped onto this virtual register file is a series of
00096  *     register banks, defined by the user which represent the
00097  *     physical register configuration of the target processor.
00098  *
00099  *     Each register bank is uniquely defined by two paramters:
00100  *        1) CLASS      - either caller or callee saved
00101  *        2) TYPE       - data type ( i.e. int, float, double, or quad )
00102  *
00103  *     In addition to the above parameters there are 3 more parameters, which
00104  *     describe the mapping of the banks into the virtual register file.
00105  *        3) NUM_REG    - number of registers in the bank
00106  *        4) REG_SIZE   - number of registers in the virtual file required by
00107  *                        each register in the bank
00108  *        5) OVERLAP    - describes the overlap conditions for example
00109  *                        float and double register files typically overlap.
00110  *
00111  *      Also, so that the register allocator may return actual machine
00112  *      register numbers to the code generator, an array of integers
00113  *      called a register * map is also required for each bank.
00114  *
00115  *      Finally, the register allocator requires a Set * so that it
00116  *      may return the set of registers used from each register bank.
00117  *
00118  *      The following is an example of one way to define the register
00119  *      configuration of the MIPS processor to the register allocator:
00120  *
00121  *      class, type, base_index, num_reg, reg_size, reg_map
00122  *
00123  * R_define_physical_bank( R_CALLER, R_INT, 8, 1, R_OVERLAP_INT, 
00124  *                          caller_int_map, &clri_set);
00125  * R_define_physical_bank( R_CALLER, R_FLOAT, 4, 1, 
00126  *                         R_OVERLAP_FLOAT|R_OVERLAP_DOUBLE, 
00127  *                          caller_flt_map, &clrf_set);
00128  * R_define_physical_bank( R_CALLER, R_DOUBLE, 4, 1, 
00129  *                         R_OVERLAP_FLOAT|R_OVERLAP_DOUBLE, 
00130  *                          caller_flt_map, &clrf_set );
00131  * R_define_physical_bank( R_CALLEE, R_INT, 9, 1, R_OVERLAP_INT,
00132  *                          callee_int_map, &clei_set);
00133  * R_define_physical_bank( R_CALLEE, R_FLOAT, 6, 1, 
00134  *                         R_OVERLAP_FLOAT|R_OVERLAP_DOUBLE,
00135  *                          callee_flt_map, &clef_set);
00136  * R_define_physical_bank( R_CALLEE, R_DOUBLE, 6, 1, 
00137  *                         R_OVERLAP_FLOAT|R_OVERLAP_DOUBLE,
00138  *                          callee_flt_map, &clef_set );
00139  *
00140  *      NOTE: It is highly recommended that the register maps provided to *
00141  *             the register allocator have the property that registers
00142  *             in non-overlapping banks have unique numbers, so that
00143  *             the register usage information returned by the register
00144  *             allocator * will be correct.  * If this is not done,
00145  *             register allocation will be done properly, but it will
00146  *             make creating your prologue much more difficult
00147  *      
00148  *      Register Maps:
00149  *      int caller_int_map[] = { 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16 };
00150  *      int callee_int_map[] = { 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 30 };
00151  *      int caller_flt_map[] = { 8, 10, 16, 18 };
00152  *      int callee_flt_map[] = { 20, 22, 24, 26, 28, 30 }; 
00153  *         ( as per the above note, the flt maps should have each number
00154  *           incremented by an amount which makes them unique from the 
00155  *           integer banks )
00156  * 
00157  *      Macroregister Banks:
00158  *      
00159  *      Macroregister banks are defined exactly as above, using the
00160  *      bank class * names: R_MACRO_CALLER and R_MACRO_CALLEE.  There
00161  *      is one exception, the * register map array for macroregisters
00162  *      must contain the macro register * name rather that the
00163  *      processor register name.
00164  *
00165  *      Example:
00166  *      int caller_macro_map[] = { L_MAC_P0, L_MAC_P1, L_MAC_P2, L_MAC_P3 }; */
00167 
00168 /*============================
00169  *  REGISTER BANK DEFINITION  
00170  *============================*/
00171 #define R_NUM_CLASS     5
00172 #define R_TYPE_INC      R_NUM_CLASS
00173 #define R_NUM_TYPES     7       /* number of bank data types */
00174 #define R_MAX_BANK      (R_NUM_TYPES*R_NUM_CLASS)
00175 
00176 typedef struct R_Physical_Bank
00177 {
00178   short defined;
00179   short rclass;                 /* rclass may be: R_CALLER, R_CALLEE      */
00180   short type;                   /* type: R_INT, R_FLOAT, etc.             */
00181   short num_reg;                /* max number of registers in bank        */
00182   short num_rot_reg;            /* number of rotating registers in bank   */
00183   short rot_reg_ofs;            /* offs. into reg map of the 
00184                                    start of rot regs                      */
00185   short num_rot_reg_alloc;      /* multiple of rot regs that must 
00186                                    be allocated                           */
00187   short reg_size;               /* size of registers in bank              */
00188   short overlap;
00189   short global_overlap;
00190   int base_index;               /* offset into register map               */
00191   Stack *avail_reg;
00192   Stack *alloc_reg;
00193   int alloc_init;
00194   int mask;                     /* member register mask */
00195   int overlap_cnt[R_NUM_TYPES];
00196 
00197   Set *used_reg;
00198 
00199   int max;                      /* internally defined fields */
00200   short res_inc;
00201 }
00202 R_Physical_Bank;

00216 /* 
00217  *  Register Bank Class 
00218  */
00219 #define R_CALLER           0    /* caller saved register bank            */
00220 #define R_CALLEE           1    /* callee saved register bank            */
00221 #define R_SPILL            2    /* spill register bank                   */
00222 #define R_MACRO_CALLER     3    /* caller saved macro register bank      */
00223 #define R_MACRO_CALLEE     4    /* callee saved macro register bank      */
00224 
00225 #define R_PREFER_SPILL  -1
00226 
00227 /*
00228  * Register Bank Type 
00229  */
00230 #define R_PREDICATE     0
00231 #define R_INT           5
00232 #define R_FLOAT         10
00233 #define R_DOUBLE        15
00234 #define R_BTR           20
00235 #define R_QUAD          25
00236 #define R_POINTER       30
00237 
00238 /*
00239  * Register Bank Overlap
00240  */
00241 #define R_OVERLAP_PREDICATE     0x01
00242 #define R_OVERLAP_INT           0x02
00243 #define R_OVERLAP_FLOAT         0x04
00244 #define R_OVERLAP_DOUBLE        0x08
00245 #define R_OVERLAP_BTR           0x10
00246 #define R_OVERLAP_QUAD          0x20
00247 #define R_OVERLAP_POINTER       0x40

00249 /*============================
00250  *  REGISTER ALLOCATION  
00251  *============================*/
00252 typedef struct R_Alloc_Info
00253 {
00254   int n_caller_used;            /* number caller registers used        */
00255   int n_callee_used;            /* number callee registers used        */
00256   Set callee_used;              /* callee registers used               */
00257   Set caller_used;              /* caller registers used               */
00258   int swap_size;                /* total swap space size =             */
00259   /*       spilled live range + swap reg */
00260   int swap_offset;              /* loc in swap space for callee swap   */
00261 }
00262 R_Alloc_Info;

00273 #define R_CB_SPLIT              0x8
00274 #define R_INSTR_SPLIT           0x10
00275 #define R_PREALLOCATED_MACRO    0x20
00276 #define R_PA_HACK               0x40
00277 #define R_MCB_PRELOAD           0x80
00278 
00279 #define R_CONTAINS_JSR          0x100
00280 
00281 #define R_LIVE_OUTSIDE_REGION   0x1000
00282 #define R_PREALLOCATED_FLYBY    0x2000
00283 #define R_REGION_CONSTRAINED    0x4000
00284 #define R_CURRENT_VREG          0x8000

00286 typedef struct R_Reg {
00287   int index;                    /* virtual register number        */
00288   unsigned short flags;         /* ????  */
00289   char rclass;                  /* virtual register class         */
00290   unsigned char type;           /* virtual register type          */
00291   unsigned char size;           /* number of bank registers req'd */
00292 
00293   char caller_benefit;          /* positive if beneficial to use
00294                                  * caller-saved register          */
00295   char callee_benefit;          /* positive if beneficial to use
00296                                  * callee-saved register          */
00297 
00298   short base_index;             /* offset into register bank      */
00299   short phys_reg;
00300   int spill_loc;                /* spill location of live range   */
00301 
00302   Set def_instr;
00303   Set ref_instr;                /* vreg referencing instructions  */
00304   Set live_range;               /* instructions w/in live range   */
00305   Set live_range_uncond;        /* instructions w/in live range on
00306                                  * TRUE predicate (for pred regs.)*/
00307   Set ref_cbs;
00308 
00309   int rotating;
00310   int nth_rot_reg;
00311 
00312   Set illegal_reg;
00313   Set constraints;
00314 
00315   struct R_Reg *pvreg;
00316 
00317   int instr_weight;             /* += 1 each instr in live range  */
00318   double ref_weight;            /* += instr wgt, for each instr
00319                                  * referencing virtual register   */
00320   double def_weight;            /* += instr wgt, for each instr
00321                                  * defining virtual registers     */
00322 
00323   /* interference graph stuff */
00324 
00325   double priority;              /* vreg coloring priority         */
00326   struct R_Arc *interfere;      /* interfering virtual registers  */
00327 
00328   struct R_Reg *nextReg;
00329 
00330   Set intf_vreg;
00331 
00332 } R_Reg;

00359 /*===========================================================*/
00360 /* Defines for accessing operation,control block and flow    */
00361 /* data structures, if they are changed from their current   */
00362 /* array structure, alteration of these defines will still   */
00363 /* permit the register allocator to function properly        */
00364 /*===========================================================*/
00365 
00366 #define VREG(a)                 ((R_Reg *) \
00367                                  HashTable_find_or_null(R_vregHashTbl,(a)))
00368 
00369 /*==========================================================*/
00370 #define IMPACT_ABS(a)           ((a>0)?a:-a)
00371 
00372 #define CALLOC(a,b)             (((b)==0)?NULL:(a *)calloc((b),sizeof(a)))
00373 #define MALLOC(a,b)             (((b)==0)?NULL:(a *)malloc((b)*sizeof(a)))
00374 #define FREE(a)                 { if ( a != NULL ) \
00375                                         free(a); \
00376                                   a = NULL; \
00377                                 }
00378 
00379 #define R_OPERAND_REG(a)       ((L_is_reg(&a)) ? a.value.r : -1 )
00380 #define R_OPERAND_MACRO(a)     ((L_is_macro(&a)) ? a.value.mac : -1 )
00381 #define R_OPERAND_TYPE(a)      ((int)L_return_old_ctype(&a))
00382 
00383 #define R_MAX(a,b)              (((a)>(b))?(a):(b))
00384 #define R_MIN(a,b)              (((a)>(b))?(b):(a))

00482 
00483   /* -Fminimize_spill_fill=(yes|no)
00484    * If 0, R_insert_jsr_spill_fill_code() spills and fills every live register
00485    * around each jsr.  If 1, we try to do things more intelligently.  If
00486    * a register is live across two jsrs, but is not used between the jsrs
00487    * (and neither jsr is predicated and there is no branch between jsrs), we
00488    * eliminiate the useless fill and spill of the register between the jsrs.
00489    *
00490    * spill r1;           spill r1;
00491    * spill r2;           spill r2;
00492    * jsr foo1            jsr foo1;
00493    * fill r1;            fill r1;
00494    * fill r2;      =>    r3 = r1++;
00495    * r3 = r1++;          spill r1
00496    * spill r1;           jsr foo2;
00497    * spill r2;           fill r1;
00498    * jsr foo2;           fill r2;
00499    * fill r1;
00500    * fill r2;
00501    *
00502    * This is a big win in straight line code with lots of jsrs, such as you
00503    * see when compiling C++. */
00504   extern int R_Minimize_Spill_Fill;
00505

00511    passed */
